body:
I confirm the same bug on Windows 8 x64 (so not related to VM environment in my case).

Same error message as Harridrone and same steps to reproduce the bug.

If it can help a bit further, after a GetLastError and a FormatMessage, the system error message is "The specified image file did not contain a resource section".

Edit : maybe affected by this unresolved SO bug (I have an AMD Radeon HD 5770) : 
[EnumDisplayDevices not returning anything](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/18832991/enumdisplaydevices-not-returning-anything)

I'm using VirtualBox on OSX and the free MS virtual machines from here: https://www.modern.ie/en-us/virtualization-tools#downloads. Windows7 and Vista were able to find monitors. XP had the "No monitors found" error as mentioned above.

glfwInit() is giving me the same "No Monitors Found" error as above.  My setup is as follows:
Compiler: Visual Studio 2013
VM Guest OS: Windows 7 Ultimate 64 bit
VM Platform: Virtualbox 4.3.24 accelerated 3d enabled
VM Host OD: Debian Linux Jessie w/Nvidia binary graphics driver

body:
Having the same issue in a Server 2012 qemu-kvm VM hooked up with PCI passthrough. The GPU actually has no physical monitors attached, but there is a framebuffer which acts as a virtual monitor. With @linkerstorm's test programs:

EnumDisplayDevicesW:

```
No display device 0 for adapter 0
Not active adapter : 1
Not active adapter : 2
Not active adapter : 3
No more adapter : 4
```

EnumDisplayMonitors:

```
Monitor: 0000000000010001 (X,Y): (0,0) (Width, Height): (1920,1080)
```

I haven't run into this issue launching any commercial games yet, so I suppose none that I tried use GLFW. SDL seems to work FWIW.

issue.body:
Running Windows 10.

I am testing my app on a Win10 home server with no physical monitor attached (I am connecting through VNC so the graphics driver still works for everything else).

Ignoring the cause of why glfwGetMonitors returns NULL for now, the documentation for glfwGetMonitors states that if it returns NULL an error has occured, however I get no error callback? This resulted in undefined behaviour as the app continued executing after glfwGetMonitors returned null (surely enough it crashes later on though).

I thought it was safe to assume that glfwSetErrorCallback will catch all errors?

body: This will have a fix in 3.2.

This issue also occurs on native Windows machines with an improper display setup (https://github.com/wjakob/instant-meshes/issues/13). However, windows and most other applications work just fine in this situation, and it is GLFW that is being extra-picky. It would be nice if the "No monitors found" error message would be a warning rather than causing glfwInit() to fail.
@wjakob That test was removed in the latest release.
